news_summary: Today's news highlights impressive achievements in securing competitive grants, intriguing discoveries about Neanderthal diets including possible maggot consumption, and fascinating prehistoric animal encounters between terror birds and caimans.
news_summary_fr: Les nouvelles d'aujourd'hui mettent en lumière des réussites impressionnantes dans l'obtention de subventions compétitives, des découvertes intrigantes sur le régime alimentaire des Néandertaliens, y compris la consommation possible d'asticots, et des rencontres préhistoriques fascinantes entre des oiseaux de terreur et des caïmans.
news_summary_es: Las noticias de hoy destacan impresionantes logros en la obtención de subvenciones competitivas, intrigantes descubrimientos sobre la dieta de los neandertales, incluido el posible consumo de gusanos, y fascinantes encuentros animales prehistóricos entre aves del terror y caimanes.

articles.title: I won three competitive grants in a row. Here’s how I learnt what to do
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01627-6It took time and rejections to understand what granting agencies look for. This is how I picked up application-writing skills.
articles.content:
Jingming Cai says he deliberately shaped his PhD's focus to prepare for future applicationsCredit: Cavan Images/Getty

After completing my PhD in engineering in September 2018, I set out to navigate the world of early-career fellowships — a path that taught me as much about resilience and strategy as it did about research.

After experiencing two rejections, rewriting my proposals and learning from every round of feedback, I have secured three major awards over the past five years: a Humboldt Research Fellowship in Germany, a Marie Skłodowska-Curie Postdoctoral Fellowship (MSCA-PF) from the European Union and a Discovery Early Career Researcher Award (DECRA) from the Australian Research Council. These totalled around US$600,000 in funding, which supported my early-stage research across multiple countries. Now, I’m an associate professor at the School of Civil Engineering at Southeast University in Nanjing, China, where I conduct research on energy technologies for buildings.

All three fellowships are highly competitive — for instance, the success rates for the MSCA-PF and DECRA were both around 15% when I applied. Each application process pushed me to reflect not only on how to write a convincing proposal, but also on who I am as a researcher, what kind of work I want to do and how to communicate that to others. Here are some lessons that I learnt the hard way — and that might help others going through the same process.

Start preparing before you finish your PhD

The best applications don’t start with a call for proposals — they start months, and sometimes years, earlier. In the final year of my PhD, I became aware of several major international fellowships for early-career researchers. With these opportunities in mind, I deliberately shaped my work to strengthen my CV and prepare for future applications. I focused on building a clear research identity: publishing in the niche but promising field of thermoelectric materials for buildings, and collaborating internationally. This helped to demonstrate that I could work across borders. These shifts weren’t always straightforward — I had to take care that my activities remained aligned with my doctoral objectives without compromising the integrity of my research.

For example, I actively took part in international academic conferences on emerging energy technologies, even though they were not entirely relevant to my core research area. These experiences later helped me to identify institutions that would be suitable hosts if I attracted funding, and to collect strong letters of recommendation.

I also learnt the importance of being flexible with my research direction. Early on I focused entirely on structural design in buildings, but I later realized that combining structural design with energy research was better suited to my strengths. It also aligned more closely with emerging needs in the field, and so would be relevant to more calls for grant funding. I think similar opportunities exist in the natural sciences, particularly because many areas are now integrating with digital tools such as artificial intelligence and the use of big data, so expertise in those areas is transferable.

Choosing a research direction that plays to your strengths and can respond to developments and demands in the field can make a real difference. I attended a number of interdisciplinary talks, which gave me a broad view of where the field was heading. I decided to shape my direction accordingly, while keeping my own interests in mind. I tried to be as independent as I could in choosing a research direction: after all, the grants I was applying for were specifically to build my own research direction.

Use early applications to practise and build confidence

I submitted my first MSCA-PF application shortly after finishing my PhD — and was rejected. The core proposal was around 15 pages long and required detailed planning of research content, collaborations and implementation. I had only three months to prepare it, and I underestimated the importance of a well-structured narrative. As a result, the submission lacked coherence and clarity, and didn’t address the scientific questions in enough depth. For example, my methodology did not include enough detail.

I asked for feedback and started again. I rewrote the proposal from scratch: clarified my role in the project, restructured the scientific goals so that they were more focused, with concrete and feasible methods, and worked closely with my collaborators and host institution. The second time around, the proposal scored 98.8 out of 100 and was awarded €189,000 (US$220,000). I used this to start my work on building energy technologies, where I made advances in the field of thermoelectric devices. My colleagues and I developed the most energy-efficient building thermoelectric module known so far, with the potential to convert urban waste heat into electricity and help to mitigate the growing challenges of the urban heat-island effect and energy crisis.

Jingming Cai learned from repeated rejection to win some big time fellowships.Credit: Jingming Cai

For those starting out, I recommend applying to fellowships with simpler formats and flexible timelines — such as those offered by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science or the Humboldt Foundation in Germany. These programmes have a more streamlined application process, focusing on the applicant’s potential and research idea, rather than requiring very detailed project planning and implementation, as the MSCA-PF does. The fellowships are highly respected and are excellent practice for applying to more complex programmes, such as European Research Council funding competitions.

Tell a story — don’t just give a technical plan

The biggest mistake I made early on was treating a fellowship application like a journal submission. My first MSCA-PF draft was packed with bullet points, dense data tables and technical language. But I learnt that reviewers aren’t just evaluating scientific merit — they’re also looking for alignment with their goals, potential to become an independent researcher and a clear narrative. And, of course, how the proposed work would contribute to solving any specific scientific or societal challenges that the fellowship aims to support.

What made the difference in my revised application was learning how to tell a compelling story: who I was, what I had done, what gap I saw in the field and how this project, in this environment, would help me to grow. I included a tailored training plan, showed how the fellowship would support my long-term goals and outlined the societal relevance of the work.

I followed a simple structure:

Background. Introduce the project using a narrative that leads from ‘everybody knows’ to ‘nobody knows’ — start with widely understood context, then narrow down to the specific research gap.

Challenge. Describe the technical bottleneck and explain why this project is needed to overcome it.

Innovation. Explain what makes the idea original and how it differs from existing approaches.

Implementation. Lay out a detailed and feasible plan to ensure timely and effective delivery of the project.

Impact. Clarify the scientific and socio-economic benefits of the project.

This breakdown made it easier for reviewers to follow the logic and understand the value of each component. I avoided jargon and assumed the reviewers were smart scientists, but not necessarily experts in my subfield.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights an individual's achievement in winning three competitive grants consecutively, emphasizing perseverance and learning from rejection. This story is inspiring and offers hope and practical advice to others seeking similar success, fitting the criteria of individual achievements that inspire.
articles.personality_title: How persistence and learning helped me win three grants in a row
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Jingming Cai, an engineer who finished his PhD in 2018, wanted to earn early-career research grants. These grants are competitive and tough to get, but they are important for starting a successful research career.

**What happened**
After two rejections, Jingming didn’t give up. He carefully rewrote his applications each time, using feedback from reviewers to improve. Over five years, this approach helped him win three major awards, including the prestigious Humboldt Research Fellowship.

**Impact**
His story shows that winning grants isn’t just about having good ideas; it’s about learning what grant agencies want and improving your proposals. This helped Jingming build a strong research career and gave him confidence to keep going despite setbacks.

**What’s next step**
Jingming plans to keep using the skills he developed in grant writing to apply for more fellowships and continue growing his research. He encourages others to see rejections as opportunities to learn and improve.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Learning from feedback and staying persistent can turn early setbacks into major successes in competitive grant applications.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment la persévérance et l’apprentissage m’ont permis de gagner trois subventions d’affilée
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Jingming Cai, ingénieur diplômé en 2018, voulait obtenir des subventions pour jeunes chercheurs. Ces subventions sont très compétitives, mais essentielles pour lancer une carrière en recherche.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Après deux refus, Jingming n’a pas abandonné. Il a retravaillé ses dossiers en tenant compte des retours des évaluateurs. En cinq ans, cette méthode lui a permis de décrocher trois grandes récompenses, dont la prestigieuse bourse Humboldt.

**Impact**
Son histoire montre que réussir à obtenir une subvention ne dépend pas seulement d’une bonne idée, mais aussi de la compréhension des attentes des agences et de l’amélioration constante des candidatures. Cela lui a permis de construire une carrière solide et de garder confiance malgré les échecs.

**Prochaine étape**
Jingming compte continuer à utiliser ses compétences en rédaction de demandes pour postuler à d’autres bourses et développer sa recherche. Il encourage à voir les refus comme des occasions d’apprendre.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Apprendre des retours et persévérer transforme les premiers échecs en succès majeurs dans les demandes de subventions compétitives.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo la perseverancia y el aprendizaje me ayudaron a ganar tres becas seguidas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Jingming Cai, ingeniero que terminó su doctorado en 2018, quería obtener becas para investigadores jóvenes. Estas becas son muy competitivas y clave para iniciar una carrera exitosa en investigación.

**Qué pasó**
Tras dos rechazos, Jingming no se rindió. Reescribió sus solicitudes usando las opiniones de los evaluadores para mejorar. En cinco años, esta estrategia le ayudó a ganar tres premios importantes, incluyendo la beca Humboldt.

**Impacto**
Su historia demuestra que ganar becas no solo depende de buenas ideas, sino también de entender qué buscan las agencias y mejorar las propuestas. Esto le ayudó a construir una carrera fuerte y a mantener la confianza pese a los contratiempos.

**Próximo paso**
Jingming planea seguir usando las habilidades que aprendió para solicitar más becas y seguir creciendo en su investigación. Anima a otros a ver los rechazos como oportunidades para aprender.

**Frase clave**
Aprender de los comentarios y ser persistente puede convertir los fracasos iniciales en grandes éxitos en solicitudes de becas competitivas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed warm drawing of a sturdy bridge made of open books spanning across a globe, with glowing thermoelectric modules embedded along the bridge’s structure symbolizing innovative energy technology, connected by shining threads of light representing international collaboration and the journey of resilience and growth in research.

articles.title: Mystery food in Neanderthal diet might be maggots
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 25 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02334-yStudy of rotting human cadavers hints that a puzzling chemical marker in Neanderthal remains could be from eating the larvae.
articles.content:
Neanderthals might have eaten maggots along with the meat they stored from hunting, researchers say.Credit: Roman Uchytel/Science Photo Library

A mysterious chemical signature seen in the remains of Neanderthals might be explained if they often snacked on a special culinary garnish: maggots. That’s according to research published today in Science Advances1.

The finding adds to the picture that researchers are painting of how our close ancient human relatives provided themselves with nourishment.

Neanderthals and humans interbred more recently than scientists thought

Scientists have long been perplexed by the fact that the bones of Neanderthals (Homo neanderthalensis) from the late Pleistocene (11,700–129,000 years ago) contain a nitrogen isotope at extreme levels2 normally seen in mega-meat-eaters such as hyenas and wolves. The more meat an animal eats, the more nitrogen-15 it stores, and those at the top of the food chain have the highest amounts.

But “our guts are not carnivore guts”, says Bruce Hardy, an anthropologist at Kenyon College in Gambier, Ohio. “Our livers can only do so much to process protein.” So the Neanderthal levels seemed impossibly high.

Melanie Beasley, an anthropologist at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana, and her colleagues wondered whether, instead of gorging on massive quantities of meat, Neanderthals raised their 15N levels by preparing their food in some unique way. Beasley, the lead author of the study, was inspired by historical examples of Indigenous groups consuming putrefied food, as well as the maggots — or fly larvae — that feast on it. Think of fermentation, she says. Putrefaction is similar: “A Westerner might say it’s rotting, but it’s really a method of storing the food to break down the meat,” she adds.

To see whether Neanderthals might have followed the same recipe, Beasley and her colleagues acquired muscle tissue samples from 34 donated human cadavers that had spent two years putrefying at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville’s Forensic Anthropology Center. They found that 15N levels in the flesh rose as it decomposed — and when they sampled hundreds of larvae in the tissue, they measured up to 43 parts per thousand isotope in the maggots compared with up to 8 parts per thousand in the tissue.

Bon appétit

Both results suggest that, if Neanderthals had enjoyed putrefied meat and maggots, it could be a more viable explanation for their puzzlingly high 15N levels than eating impossibly large quantities of meat. And it’s probably a more well-rounded meal than eating just protein, Beasley says. “When you get the lean meat and the fatty maggot, you have a more complete nutrient that you’re consuming.”
articles.reasoning: The article presents a scientific discovery that sheds light on Neanderthal diet, which is an interesting advancement in understanding human history. While it may not be directly uplifting or immediately impactful on daily life, it contributes positively to scientific knowledge and curiosity.
articles.personality_title: Neanderthals might have spiced up their meals with maggots
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long studied Neanderthal diets to better understand how these ancient humans lived. Recently, a puzzling chemical marker found in their remains left researchers wondering what it could mean.

**What happened**
New research suggests that this chemical signature could come from Neanderthals eating maggots, the larvae found on rotting meat. By studying how chemicals develop on decaying human bodies, scientists noticed similarities with the markers in Neanderthal bones. This hints that alongside meat, Neanderthals might have eaten these larvae, possibly as a nutritional supplement.

**Impact**
This discovery gives us a clearer picture of Neanderthal eating habits and shows they might have used a wider variety of food sources than previously thought. It also highlights their resourcefulness in using available food, even those we might consider unusual today.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to study more Neanderthal sites and remains to see if these chemical markers appear elsewhere. They also hope to understand better how eating maggots affected Neanderthals’ health and nutrition.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Neanderthals may have boosted their meals with maggots, revealing a surprising and smart part of their diet.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les néandertaliens pourraient avoir agrémenté leurs repas de vers de farine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques étudient depuis longtemps l'alimentation des néandertaliens pour mieux comprendre leur mode de vie. Récemment, un marqueur chimique mystérieux trouvé dans leurs restes a intrigué les chercheurs.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Une nouvelle recherche suggère que ce marqueur chimique pourrait venir des vers de farine, les larves trouvées sur la viande en décomposition, que les néandertaliens auraient mangés. En étudiant les produits chimiques sur des corps humains en décomposition, les scientifiques ont trouvé des similitudes avec ceux présents dans les os de néandertaliens. Cela laisse penser qu'en plus de la viande, ils consommaient ces larves, peut-être comme complément nutritionnel.

**Impact**
Cette découverte nous donne une image plus claire des habitudes alimentaires des néandertaliens et montre qu'ils utilisaient probablement une plus grande diversité d’aliments qu’on ne le pensait. Elle souligne aussi leur ingéniosité à utiliser toutes les ressources alimentaires disponibles, même celles qui nous paraissent étranges aujourd’hui.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs veulent étudier davantage de sites et de restes néandertaliens pour voir si ces marqueurs chimiques se retrouvent ailleurs. Ils espèrent aussi mieux comprendre l’impact de ces vers sur la santé et la nutrition des néandertaliens.

**Une phrase clé**
Les néandertaliens auraient enrichi leurs repas avec des vers de farine, révélant un aspect surprenant et ingénieux de leur régime alimentaire.
articles.personality_title_es: Los neandertales podrían haber añadido gusanos a sus comidas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos llevan tiempo estudiando la dieta de los neandertales para entender mejor cómo vivían. Recientemente, un marcador químico misterioso encontrado en sus restos llamó la atención de los investigadores.

**Qué pasó**
Una nueva investigación sugiere que ese marcador químico podría provenir de que los neandertales comieran gusanos, las larvas que se encuentran en carne en descomposición. Al estudiar cómo se forman estos químicos en cuerpos humanos en descomposición, los científicos vieron similitudes con los marcadores en huesos neandertales. Esto indica que, además de carne, podrían haber consumido estas larvas como suplemento nutricional.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo nos da una imagen más clara de los hábitos alimenticios de los neandertales y muestra que probablemente usaban una variedad más amplia de alimentos de lo que se pensaba. También destaca su habilidad para aprovechar todos los recursos alimenticios disponibles, incluso los que hoy consideraríamos inusuales.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean estudiar más restos y sitios neandertales para ver si estos marcadores químicos aparecen en otros lugares. También quieren entender mejor cómo comer gusanos afectaba a la salud y nutrición de los neandertales.

**Una frase clave**
Los neandertales podrían haber mejorado sus comidas con gusanos, mostrando un lado sorprendente e inteligente de su dieta.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a prehistoric stone table holding a rustic wooden platter with stylized maggots crawling over aged, decomposing meat, set against a soft earthy background that symbolizes ancient nourishment and the unique Neanderthal diet.

articles.title: Rumble in the Miocene: terror bird versus caiman
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02308-0Toothmarks on a fossilized bone tell a story of two mega-predators.
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: The article reveals scientific insights about prehistoric life through fossil evidence, which contributes to our understanding of natural history and evolution. While it doesn't directly involve human welfare or environmental progress, it represents a positive scientific discovery that can inspire curiosity and appreciation for the natural world.
articles.personality_title: Fossil clues reveal epic showdown between prehistoric predators
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have uncovered fascinating new evidence about the fierce battles that happened millions of years ago, during the Miocene era. This time period, around 15 million years ago, was home to incredible creatures now long vanished from Earth.

**What happened**
Researchers found a fossilized bone marked with tooth impressions, telling the story of a fight between two giant predators: a terror bird and a caiman. Terror birds were large, flightless birds known for their powerful beaks, while caimans are relatives of crocodiles. The toothmarks help scientists understand how these animals hunted and interacted.

**Impact**
This discovery sheds light on the complex food chain and survival struggles in prehistoric times. By studying such fossils, scientists learn more about evolution and animal behavior long before humans existed. It sparks curiosity and gives us a deeper appreciation for the natural world’s history.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to examine other fossils in the area to build a clearer picture of the ancient ecosystem. This could reveal more surprising interactions among extinct species and help build knowledge that informs both science and education.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A fossilized bone with toothmarks opens a window into a dramatic prehistoric battle, enriching our understanding of ancient life on Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des indices fossiles révèlent un affrontement épique entre prédateurs préhistoriques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Des scientifiques ont découvert de nouvelles preuves fascinantes sur les combats féroces qui ont eu lieu il y a des millions d'années, durant l'ère du Miocène. Cette période, il y a environ 15 millions d'années, abritait des créatures incroyables aujourd'hui disparues.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont trouvé un os fossile marqué par des empreintes de dents, racontant l'histoire d’un combat entre deux énormes prédateurs : un oiseau-terreur et un caïman. Les oiseaux-terreur étaient de grands oiseaux incapables de voler, connus pour leurs puissants becs, tandis que les caïmans sont des proches des crocodiles. Ces marques dentaires aident les scientifiques à comprendre comment ces animaux chassaient et interagissaient.

**Impact**
Cette découverte éclaire la chaîne alimentaire complexe et les luttes pour la survie à l’époque préhistorique. En étudiant ces fossiles, les scientifiques en apprennent davantage sur l’évolution et le comportement animal bien avant l’apparition des humains. Cela suscite la curiosité et nous donne une meilleure appréciation de l’histoire du monde naturel.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d’examiner d’autres fossiles dans la région pour mieux comprendre l’écosystème ancien. Cela pourrait révéler d’autres interactions surprenantes entre espèces éteintes et enrichir les connaissances scientifiques et éducatives.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Un os fossile marqué de dents ouvre une fenêtre sur un combat préhistorique dramatique, enrichissant notre compréhension de la vie ancienne sur Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Restos fósiles revelan un enfrentamiento épico entre depredadores prehistóricos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Científicos han descubierto nuevas pruebas fascinantes sobre las feroces peleas ocurridas hace millones de años, durante la época del Mioceno. Este periodo, hace unos 15 millones de años, albergaba criaturas increíbles que hoy han desaparecido.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores encontraron un hueso fosilizado con marcas de dientes, que cuentan la historia de una pelea entre dos grandes depredadores: un ave terror y un caimán. Las aves terror eran grandes aves no voladoras, conocidas por sus fuertes picos, mientras que los caimanes son parientes de los cocodrilos. Las marcas de dientes ayudan a los científicos a entender cómo cazaban e interactuaban estos animales.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento arroja luz sobre la compleja cadena alimenticia y las luchas por la supervivencia en tiempos prehistóricos. Al estudiar estos fósiles, los científicos aprenden más sobre la evolución y el comportamiento animal mucho antes de la llegada de los humanos. Esto despierta curiosidad y nos da una mayor apreciación por la historia del mundo natural.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean examinar otros fósiles en la zona para construir una imagen más clara del ecosistema antiguo. Esto podría revelar interacciones sorprendentes entre especies extintas y ayudar a ampliar el conocimiento científico y educativo.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Un hueso fosilizado con marcas de dientes abre una ventana a una batalla prehistórica dramática, enriqueciendo nuestra comprensión de la vida antigua en la Tierra.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a prehistoric scene showing a towering terror bird with vibrant feathers facing off gently with a large, calm caiman partially submerged in a serene Miocene wetland, both animals rendered with natural earthy tones and soft lighting that highlights their majestic forms in a peaceful coexistence.
